title: Epigenetic mechanisms of rapid-acting antidepressants

background: Rapid-acting antidepressants (RAADs) improve psychiatric disorders by modulating neuroplasticity, neurotransmission, and immunity, potentially through epigenetic mechanisms.
hypotheses: Whether epigenetic changes causally contribute to the therapeutic effects of RAADs, are a consequence thereof, or are unrelated remains unknown.
Psilocybin might increase telomerase activity and telomere length.
Ayahuasca might extinguish the fear response via an epigenetic mechanism mediated by the DMT-activated Sigma-1 receptor.
RAADs might directly interact with DNA, histones, or chromatin remodeling complexes, thus acting as direct epigenetic modulators.
major_findings: Preliminary evidence indicates that administration of RAADs is accompanied by epigenetic effects which are similar to those elicited by conventional antidepressants.
Ketamine restores some of the stress-induced aberrant DNA methylation, including on the BDNF gene.
Repeated LSD largely increased the methylation level of 635 CpG sites in the PFC of adult male mice.
MDMA-assisted psychotherapy led to peripheral epigenetic changes correlated to therapeutic improvement.
Repeated ketamine during early gestation decreases the cardiac histone H3K9 acetylation level, leading to cardiac enlargement.
